awd_titl_txt: Advanced Cyberinfrastructure for Teaching and Research at Rowan University and the Southern New Jersey Region
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Over the last several years, Rowan University has seen an increase in computational research, teaching, and innovation activities. Rowan faces a challenge in supporting the diverse and growing computational needs of its faculty, while also developing a plan for optimal investment in institutional infrastructure.  To this end, Rowan University is planning for a cyberinfrastructure that can sustainably support this increased activity.  The work generates institutional knowledge that will allow Rowan, its community college affiliates & partners, and other regional universities to reach the full potential of its faculty and students in conducting larger scale transformative work and increase their competitiveness in data-driven computational research.

The CC* Planning Grant addresses the challenge of building cyberinfrastructure (CI).  Early analysis on the gap between the needs of the university (and Southern New Jersey region) and the barriers for accessing state of the art cyberinfrastructure revealed the following needs: assessment and self-study to understand researchers needs, planning at the institutional level for financing CI needs, and student engagement and training related to computational research & experimentation.  The project focuses on strategic planning in order to develop a coordinated approach that informs the communities in Southern New Jersey of the latest CI developments, assesses the stakeholders’ needs and Rowan’s capacity to support those needs, builds partnerships with other institutions for sustainable regional based computing, and develops a robust plan that will enable Rowan to build shared and accessible CI.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The project, titled “Advanced Cyberinfrastructure for Teaching and Research at Rowan University and the Southern New Jersey Region” aimed to understand the advanced computing and cyberinfrastructure needs for faculty and students at Rowan University and at partner institutions in the southern New Jersey region.  The project is a partnership between NJ Edge and Rowan University with participation extended to two partner community colleges, Rowan College at South Jersey and Rowan College at Burlington County.  

Intellectual Merit:

Beginning in August 2021, Rowan University launched a comprehensive assessment of research IT needs across Rowan University faculties, in order to identify the actual support needs and existing service gaps in meeting the needs of Rowan’s modern, computationally intensive research enterprise. The assessment was motivated by a recognition that research methods and domains had changed dramatically over the years, while IT services and support structures tended to change more incrementally. The final findings and recommendations were developed as a CI report, and the process culminated with findings and recommendations, categorized into the areas of People, Process, and Technology, across the university. Following the release of the CI report, Rowan’s vice president for information technology, vice president for research and innovation, and director  for library affairs teamed up with others to identify next steps of the effort, starting with developing a proposal to meet the needs expressed by faculty, which encompass much more than IT. 

Based on analysis and further refinement based on Rowan community feedback, Recommendations were made  for implementation, comprising several overarching service clusters: (1) Better Support for Researchers by Adding Personnel, Improving Coordination, and Easing Service Discovery, (2) Enhance Computational Services and Build Capacity for Data-Intensive Research, and (3) Balance Security and Compliance Requirements with Flexibility Needed to Support Different Types of Researchers.  These overarching clusters reflect a coordinated and integrated research support program across the Office for Research, Office of Information Technology (OIT), Rowan University Libraries, and others.  Addressing the needs includes targets for future funding opportunities. The result of the assessment was presented to the cross-functional team. The three phases of the initiative included Assessment, Recommendations, and Implementation. 

An important outcome  of the project is the internal partnerships and community that has emerged that includes processes for communication.  This community was largely developed around the seminar series on Advanced Computing to network/cohort, engage and educate.  Other project outcomes are:

 

  • CI Strategy Development and prioritization process for next steps from recommendations and prioritize based on the categories of recommendation to identify next steps;

  • Development of a 5 year CI plan;

  • Development of a longer and more comprehensive Research CyberInfrastructure:  Supporting the Road to R1 (dated March 2023) prepared by the Office of the CIO;

  • An presentation at the EDUCAUSE Annual Meeting Titled:  "Advancing Cyberinfrastructure for Research at an Emerging R1 Institution" with Co-authors:  Mira Lalovic-Hand, Tabbetha Dobbins, and Forough Ghahramani on October 18, 2023 (Online Session);

  • Manuscript in preparation for PEARC ‘24;

  • Identified funding opportunities for addressing some of the outcomes culminating with a submission of an NSF CC* Area 3 proposal in the Fall of 2023.

  • Rowan University was engaged in the broader research computing community through the ERN, the NSF PI meeting, the Quilt. 

 

Broader Impacts:

Co-PI Bouaynaya contributed to the Learning and Workforce Development (LWD) by engaging undergraduate and graduate students in the College of Engineering in high-performance computing, campus cyberinfrastructure, data integrity, privacy, and federated access through Engineering Clinic programs and NSF-funded basic research tasks, which are data-, memory-, and compute-intensive. In particular, students interacted and worked with IRT to install and configure new Lambda machines, which supplement Rowan’s HPC, and serve the needs of the artificial intelligence community on campus. 

We extended invitations to our partner community colleges and the engagement, while limited, included their participation on the seminar series and utilizing this network to be informed about upcoming workshops offered by the broader research computing community (i.e. the ERN and Quilt).  

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2023
Modified by: Tabbetha A Dobbins

The project, titled Advanced Cyberinfrastructure for Teaching and Research at Rowan University and the Southern New Jersey Region aimed to understand the advanced computing and cyberinfrastructure needs for faculty and students at Rowan University and at partner institutions in the southern New Jersey region. The project is a partnership between NJ Edge and Rowan University with participation extended to two partner community colleges, Rowan College at South Jersey and Rowan College at Burlington County. 


Intellectual Merit:


Beginning in August 2021, Rowan University launched a comprehensive assessment of research IT needs across Rowan University faculties, in order to identify the actual support needs and existing service gaps in meeting the needs of Rowans modern, computationally intensive research enterprise. The assessment was motivated by a recognition that research methods and domains had changed dramatically over the years, while IT services and support structures tended to change more incrementally. The final findings and recommendations were developed as a CI report, and the process culminated with findings and recommendations, categorized into the areas of People, Process, and Technology, across the university. Following the release of the CI report, Rowans vice president for information technology, vice president for research and innovation, and director for library affairs teamed up with others to identify next steps of the effort, starting with developing a proposal to meet the needs expressed by faculty, which encompass much more than IT.


Based on analysis and further refinement based on Rowan community feedback, Recommendations were made for implementation, comprising several overarching service clusters: (1) Better Support for Researchers by Adding Personnel, Improving Coordination, and Easing Service Discovery, (2) Enhance Computational Services and Build Capacity for Data-Intensive Research, and (3) Balance Security and Compliance Requirements with Flexibility Needed to Support Different Types of Researchers. These overarching clusters reflect a coordinated and integrated research support program across the Office for Research, Officeof Information Technology (OIT), Rowan University Libraries, and others. Addressing the needs includes targets for future funding opportunities. The result of the assessment was presented to the cross-functional team. The three phases of the initiative included Assessment, Recommendations, and Implementation.


An important outcome of the project is the internal partnerships and community that has emerged that includes processes for communication. This community was largely developed around the seminar series on Advanced Computing to network/cohort, engage and educate. Other project outcomes are:




CI Strategy Development and prioritization process for next steps from recommendations and prioritize based on the categories of recommendation to identify next steps;



Development of a 5 year CI plan;




Development of a longer and more comprehensive Research CyberInfrastructure: Supporting the Road to R1 (dated March 2023) prepared by the Office of the CIO;




An presentation at the EDUCAUSE Annual Meeting Titled: "Advancing Cyberinfrastructure for Research at an Emerging R1 Institution" with Co-authors: Mira Lalovic-Hand, Tabbetha Dobbins, and Forough Ghahramani on October 18, 2023 (Online Session);

Identified funding opportunities for addressing some of the outcomes culminating with a submission of an NSF CC* Area 3 proposal in the Fall of 2023.




Rowan University was engaged in the broader research computing community through the ERN, the NSF PI meeting, the Quilt.







Broader Impacts:


Co-PI Bouaynaya contributed to the Learning and Workforce Development (LWD) by engaging undergraduate and graduate students in the College of Engineering in high-performance computing, campus cyberinfrastructure, data integrity, privacy, and federated access through Engineering Clinic programs and NSF-funded basic research tasks, which are data-, memory-, and compute-intensive. In particular, students interacted and worked with IRT to install and configure new Lambda machines, which supplement Rowans HPC, and serve the needs of the artificial intelligence community on campus.


We extended invitations to our partner community colleges and the engagement, while limited, included their participation on the seminar series and utilizing this network to be informed about upcoming workshops offered by the broader research computing community (i.e. the ERN and Quilt).
